Effects of MgO doping in Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts forthe hydrogenation of perfluoro olefin Yanzhao Gao a b Xianglei Meng b c Shiqi Huang a b Hui Wu b c Liantao Jiang b c Yu Zhou a Yuting Song b c ⁎ Yanyan Diao b c d ⁎ a College of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 211816, China College of Chemical Engineering Nanjing Tech University Nanjing 211816 China aCollege of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 211816, China b Beijing Key Laboratory of Ionic Liquids Clean Process, CAS Key Laboratory of Green Process and Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Multiphase Complex Systems, Institute of Process Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100190, China Beijing Key Laboratory of Ionic Liquids Clean Process CAS Key Laboratory of Green Process and Engineering State Key Laboratory of Multiphase Complex Systems Institute of Process Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100190 China bBeijing Key Laboratory of Ionic Liquids Clean Process, CAS Key Laboratory of Green Process and Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Multiphase Complex Systems, Institute of Process Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100190, China c College of Chemical and Engineering, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China College of Chemical and Engineering University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China cCollege of Chemical and Engineering, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China d School of Chemical & Environmental Engineering, China University of Mining and Technology (Beijing), Beijing 100083, China School of Chemical & Environmental Engineering China University of Mining and Technology (Beijing) Beijing 100083 China dSchool of Chemical & Environmental Engineering, China University of Mining and Technology (Beijing), Beijing 100083, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Gamma alumina is widely utilized for preparing the supported noble metal catalysts for the hydrogenation reaction. It is an effective strategy to improve the catalytic performance of catalysts via modifying gamma alumina with alkaline earth metal to regulate its surface acidity and electronic properties. Herein, Pd catalysts supported by Al2O3 and Mg-modified Al2O3 are synthesized via the wet impregnation method, and the effects of MgO doping on the structure, composition, and surface acidity of Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts are investigated via X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD), Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Temperature programmed desorption (TPD). The results show that Pd/MgO-Al2O3–2 (γ-Al2O3 modified with 2 wt% Mg) has more metallic state palladium and weak acid sites and exhibits the best catalytic performance for the hydrogenation of perfluoro-4-methyl-2-pentene (D1). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations on Pd/Al2O3 and Pd/MgO-Al2O3–2 catalysts are also performed to further explore the mechanism of D1 hydrogenation. The studies for Gibbs free energy of the potential reaction steps and intermediates reveal a complex process to generate the target product C6F12H2, and the rate-determining-step is the addition of the first hydrogen on the second carbon of perfluoro-4-methyl-2-pentene molecule. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Perfluoro olefin Hydrogenation Hydrofluorocarbons Density functional theory Reaction mechanism Pd/MgO-Al2O3 catalysts Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Fluorine chemical products with their chemical resistance, high and low- temperature resistance, aging resistance, low friction, insulation, and other excellent properties, have made great contributions to chemical, mechanical, and other fields [1–7]. It has become one of the fastest growing, most high-tech, and most promising industries in the chemical industry. Fluorochemicals such as hydrofluoroolefins (HFO) and hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) are widely used as separation media, detergents, refrigerants, and extraction solvents due to high dielectric properties and hydrophobicity nature [8–12]. Hydrogenation is an essential process in the synthesis of fluorine chemical products [13–15]. The noble metal catalyst is a kind of common hydrogenation catalyst. Because of the unfilled d-electron orbital of noble metals, the reactant molecules are easy to adsorb and dissociate on the surface, ensuring good catalytic activity and selectivity [16–18]. Owing to its unique volume effect, surface effect, and quantum size effect, the Pd catalyst has become a typical noble metal catalyst in hydrogenation reactions. The earliest reports of heterogeneous hydrogenation of perfluoro olefin can trace back to the research of Russian chemist Ivan Ludvigovich Knunyants who systematically studied the heterogeneous hydrogenation of perfluoro olefin from C2 to C6 [19–21]. The hydrogenation of perfluoroethylene, perfluoropropene, perfluoroisobutene over Pd catalysts can proceed smoothly at 20 °C with a yield of 96%, while the reaction on Ni catalysts is more difficult and has more by-products. Simultaneously, in the case of hydrogenation for perfluoro olefins increases from C2 to C6, because the hydrogenation rate depends on the π bond state of the olefin and increases with the decrease of its electron density, which is consistent with the research of the usual olefins hydrogenation [20]. In addition to the synthetic challenges that represent the hydrogenation of this class compound, it is critical to find ways to selectively promote hydrogenation over the competitive defluorination side-reaction. Therefore, it is relatively difficult to obtain hydrofluorocarbons by hydrogenation. Recently, hydrofluorocarbons, mainly 1,1,1,2,3,4,5,5,5-nonafluoro-2-(trifluoromethyl) pentane (C6F12H2) are considered as a useful refrigerant in the future of electronics. Snegirev et al. studied and obtained products with various numbers of hydrogens by regulating the molar ratio of perfluoro-2-methyl-2-pentene (C6F12, D2) /NaBH4 on Pd/C catalyst with the exist of NaBH4 in −50 °C [21]. Douglas R et al. reported a route to obtain high-purity products with no catalyst utilized, which was performed with harsh reaction conditions (pressure up to 10.35 MPa) [22]. These synthesis schemes were conducted under high pressure and low temperature, requiring strict reaction conditions and safety performance of the reactor. Although the investigation, to date, has obtained a high conversion, selectivity, and purity, there are quite a few studies on the mechanism. It is worth noting that C6F12H2 can be obtained by perfluoro-4-methyl-2-pentene (C6F12, D1) hydrogenation, isomeride of D2, and D1 has less toxicity and higher stability than D2 [21]. One of the main challenges when using D1 hydrogenation to obtain C6F12H2 is to achieve high selectivity. D1, the powerful electronegative effect of CF3 renders an adjacent double bond to an electron-deficient state, induces polarization and makes the central carbon more negative, making the addition difficult [23,24]. Simultaneously, the interaction between the strong acid sites of the catalyst and the fluorine of products induces the dehydrofluorination, which is an important step in the cleavage of the C-F bond [25–27]. Gamma alumina (γ-Al2O3) is a key industrial material for supporting noble metals to prepare catalysts because of its high specific surface area and adjustable surface property [28,29]. However, γ-Al2O3 modified by alkali metal or alkaline earth metal with appropriate acid sites shows much higher catalytic activity for catalytic reactions such as CO oxidative coupling to dimethyl oxalate (DMO) [30], partial hydrogenation of acetylene [31,32], oxidation of toluene [33], carbon dioxide reforming of methane [34], hydrogenation of 2-ethyl-9,10-anthraquione [35], mercaptan oxidation [36], CO oxidation [37,38], CO + NO reaction [39], glycerol steam reforming reaction for hydrogen production [40]. The latter one possesses the right amount of acid sites or appropriate acid strength to avoid carbon deposition and catalyst deactivation, and on the other hand, the previous studies have shown that the modified carriers supported nanoparticles have a higher dispersion and smaller diameter to a certain degree. In other words, the metallics are electron-deficient on acidic carriers and electron-rich on alkaline carriers [31,41,42], increasing the C = C electron density to activate the C = C and inhibit the dehydrofluorination. In this work, we prepared a series of Pd catalysts supported by Al2O3 and modified Al2O3 via the wet impregnation method to obtain C6F12H2 via D1 hydrogenation, and focused on the effect of MgO loading on the catalyst structure and performance. The stability of Pd/MgO-Al2O3–2 experiments were performed to assess catalytic performance. Finally, experimental characterizations and DFT calculations revealed the mechanism of D1 hydrogenation over the Pd catalysts. Experimental section Materials Neutral, acid and alkaline γ-Al2O3(≥92%, 80∼150 mesh), activated clay was purchased from Macklin. NaCl, NH2 NH2 and Mg(CH3COO)2·4H2O were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent. CsF and NaBH4 purchased from Aladdin. Zn(NO3)2·6H2O was purchased from Xilong Scientific. PdCl2 was purchased from GRIKIN Advanced Materials. Bar γ-Al2O3 was bought from Tianjin Chemical Research Institute. Catalysts preparation Synthesis of MgO-Al2O3 or ZnO-Al2O3 or CsF-Al2O3 The bar γ-Al2O3 was crushed into powder and sieved to 80∼100 mesh. Prior to supporting the active component, the γ-Al2O3 were calcined at 600 °C for 3 h. The modified γ-Al2O3 supports were prepared based on the following procedure. The Mg(CH3COO)2·4H2O (Mg: 2 wt%) solution was heated at 80 °C under magnetic stirring, and then appropriate amounts of γ-Al2O3 were added into the solution and maintained at that temperature for 3 h. After impregnation, the obtained product was collected via filtration and dried under vacuum at 80 °C for 12 h, and then calcined at 600 °C for 3 h. The supports ZnO-Al2O3(Zn: 2 wt%), CsF-Al2O3(Cs: 2 wt%) and a series of MgO-Al2O3 (4 wt%, 6 wt%, 8 wt%) supports were obtained by the similar procedure. Synthesis of Pd catalysts The procedure for synthesizing Pd catalysts was reported by Qi et al. [43]. PdCl4 2−is not stable in contact with Al2O3 and it tough hydrolysis to form PdCl4-x(H2O)x (x-2) depending on the concertation of chloride ions [43–45]. PdCl2 and NaCl (n(PdCl2): n(NaCl) = 1:15) were mixed in deionized water and processed with ultrasonic to obtain aqueous solution of Na2PdCl4 [46]. And then the brown Na2PdCl4 solution was added drop-wise into the water with appropriate amounts γ-Al2O3 support at 80 °C and vigorously stirred for 1 h. and was reduced by a hydrazine hydrate solution at 80 °C for 3 h. The obtained product was collected by filtration and washed with water several times, and finally dried under a vacuum oven at 45 °C for 12 h (denoted as Pd/Al2O3). Catalysts 1 wt% Pd/MgO-Al2O3 (Mg: 2 wt%, 4 wt%, 6 wt%, 8 wt%, denoted as Pd/MgO-Al2O3–2, Pd/MgO-Al2O3–4, Pd/MgO-Al2O3–6, Pd/MgO-Al2O3–8, respectively), 1 wt% Pd/ neutral γ-Al2O3 (denoted as Pd/n Al2O3), 1 wt% Pd/ acid γ-Al2O3 (denoted as Pd/ac Al2O3), 1 wt% Pd/ alkaline γ-Al2O3 (denoted as Pd/al Al2O3), 1 wt% Pd/ ZnO-Al2O3 (Zn: 2 wt%, denoted as Pd/ZnO-Al2O3), 1 wt% Pd/CsF-Al2O3 (Cs: 2 wt%, denoted as Pd/CsF-Al2O3) were obtained with the same procedure. The as-prepared Pd/Al2O3 catalysts were reduced by NaBH4 at room temperature for 1 h and reduced by 10 % H2 in Ar reduced at 400 °C for 4 h (denoted as Pd/Al2O3 NaBH4 and Pd/Al2O3 H2). Catalyst characterization The powder X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD) of samples were performed on a Rigaku D8MAX-2400 diffractometer using Cu-Kα radiation (40 kV and 200 mA) at room temperature, the range of 2θ was 10 ° - 90 ° with scanning rate of 10 °·min−1. The textual parameters of as-prepared catalysts were confirmed via Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) characterization. The samples were degassed at 0.1 Torr and 350 °C for 3 h before the test. The nitrogen adsorption and desorption experiments were conducted at 77 K on the ASAP 2460 instrument. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was determined on a Kratos AXIS Supra apparatus using monochromatic Al Ka X-ray (1486.7 eV) to obtain the binding energy and chemical state of Pd species. The binding energy values were calibrated for the charging effect by referring to the adventitious C1s line at 284.8 eV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded on a JEOL JEM-2100F and JEM-F200 microscope, operating at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Temperature Programmed Desorption (TPD, NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD) were conducted on a Micrometrics Auto Chem II 2920 chemisorption instrument with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The sample (0.05 g) was loaded into a U-shape quartz reactor and heated to 120 °C for 0.5 h at 10 °C min−1 in He gas, then cooled to 50 °C. Next, the flowing gas was switched to a 10 vol% CO2 or NH3 in the He for 1 h to ensure maximum adsorption. Finally, the sample was purged with He to remove the physically adsorbed CO2 or NH3 for 0.5 h. The sample was heated in He streams from room temperature to 550 °C (10 °C min−1). Catalyst performance evaluation Catalytic testing The reaction was carried out in a 100 ml 316 L stainless-steel autoclave with Teflon vessel. In a typical procedure, 0.4 g catalyst, and 11.5 g D1 were placed into the reactor simultaneously and sealed quickly. The reactor and catalyst were pressurized to 1 MPa with hydrogen, heated to the target reaction temperature of 80 °C, and stirred for 6 h. After the reaction time reached, the reaction was cooled to room temperature, and the hydrogen inside the reactor was evacuated. The liquid products were separated from the solid through filtration and analyzed using Agilent 6890 gas chromatography equipped with a capillary column (DB-624, 30 m) and FID detector. The conversion rate and selectivity rate were calculated through the following equation: Conv ersi on = D 1 init ial − D 1 final D 1 init ial × 100 % Sele ctiv ity = D H final D 1 init ial − D 1 final × 100 % The target product, C6F12H2 is denoted as DH. The structure of C6F12H2 is determined via IR and NMR analysis (Fig. S1 and Fig. S2, Table S1). The main side-products were prepared and determined via IR and NMR analysis as shown in supporting information (Fig. S1 and Fig. S2, Table S1). The stability of the catalyst was evaluated using a fixed-bed microreactor, in which the catalyst was loaded into a quartz tube. Before stability tests, the catalyst was pretreated in 30 SCCM N2 at room temperature for 0.5 h to remove any impurities. D1 at 0.1 ml/min was introduced into the catalyst by an injection pump, and the H2 flow rate was 30 sccm and at 1.0 MPa by a mass flow meter control. The space velocity was 179.7 h − 1 (at 3.0 g catalyst), and the residence time was 20 s. The reactor was heated to 120 °C and held until the system reached a steady state. The product gas was cooled to room temperature, and collected and then analyzed via a gas chromatography instrument (Agilent 6890). The conversion rate and selectivity rate were calculated as the above method. Computational calculations All density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted using the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) [47,48], the projector augmented wave (PAW) method [49], and the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) of the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional [50]. The PAW method with a plane wave basis setting with a kinetic energy cutoff of 450 eV was adopted to describe the interaction between ions and electrons. Meanwhile, the DFT-D3 empirical calibration method was employed to take into account Van der Waals interactions. Geometry optimizations were performed with the force convergency less than 0.05 eV/Å. Monkhorst-Pack k-points of 1 × 1 × 1 was applied for all the calculations. In the catalyst model, the structural model of γ-Al2O3 (100) was selected according to a previous study [51–53], the bulk structure was adopted from a previous study [52,53], the Pd/MgO-Al2O3–2(100) was modelled by doping several Mg atoms on the Al2O3(100) surface or subsurface, and Pd13 cluster supported by MgO-Al2O3(100) surface [49,54]. In this work, the Gibbs free energy (ΔG) for each step of D1 hydrogenation on the Pd/ Al2O3(100) and Pd/MgO-Al2O3–2(100) process was calculated by Δ G = Δ E + Δ Z P E − T Δ S Where ΔE is the energy change obtained from DFT calculations, ΔZPE and ΔS are changes in the zero-point energy and the entropy at 300 K, respectively. Results and discussion Catalyst characterizations XRD and BET analysis The crystallographic structures of Pd catalysts supported by Al2O3 and modified Al2O3 were investigated by XRD. As shown in Fig. 1 , diffraction peaks at 2θ = 37.6°, 39.5°, 45.9°, 67° (JCPDS 00–010–0425) ascribed to the characteristic peaks of γ-Al2O3 [55]. The diffraction peaks broadening degree of commercial neutral, acid and alkaline γ-Al2O3 is slightly larger than the γ-Al2O3 tested, which is due to the particle size is large than latter. After Al3+cations were partly substituted by Zn2+cations, Mg2+cations, Cs+cations at the interface or subsurface, the diffraction peaks slightly shifted to a lower diffraction angle [30]. However, diffraction peaks of Pd were not detected in the catalysts, which is due to the low Pd loading and high dispersion of Pd nanoparticles (NPs) on the supports. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and corresponding pore-structure distribution profiles of the catalysts are shown in Fig. S3; the detailed textural properties are listed in Table S2. All the samples showed a typical type-IV isotherm with an H1-shaped hysteresis loop at a relative pressure (P/P0) between 0.6 and 1.0 [32], indicating uniform cylindrical pores. The pore diameter distribution profiles are almost the same for all samples after the addition of Mg. NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD analysis The C-F bond cleavage was the rate-determining step in the dehydrofluorination process of HFC compounds. The C-F bond cleavage was induced by the interaction between the strong acid sites of catalysts and the F atoms [25–27], thus, NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD were performed to study the effect of MgO on surface basicity and acidity. Three peaks (Fig. 2 a) were detected in the Pd/Al2O3 sample, centering at 100 °C, 170 °C and 400 °C, corresponding to weak, moderate and strong acid sites, respectively [30,56]. The strength of NH3 desorption peak decreased with the introduction of Mg; The peak area was used as a descriptor to further quantify the acidity and clarify the relation between Mg content and the acidity. The peak area was determined via deconvolution of peaks with Gaussian and Lorentz functions. The results are exhibited in Fig. 2 and Table 1 . With the increase of Mg addition, the peak area of weak acid and strong acid first increased and then decreased, while the peak area of moderate acid showed a reverse trend. Since the acid of catalysts was ascribed to the Lewis acid sites of Al2O3 that adopt electrons, the variation of acidity could be attributed to the electron transfer from Mg to the Lewis acid sites in the Al2O3 support [56,57]. As is expected, the addition of Mg leads to different level of increase in the amount of basic sites and basic strength. According to CO2 desorption temperature, the basicity of samples can be divided into two parts: weak basicity (ca. 100 °C), medium basicity (178∼350 °C) [30,31,56], which could be related to the lattice bound -OH or surface hydroxyl groups, metal-oxygen pairs and low-coordination surface O2− [31]. Moreover, no obvious strong basic sites (>400 °C) were observed on the catalysts surface [40,58]. Compared with Pd/Al2O3, the changes of the weak basic sites with MgO coating were not obvious, while the moderate basic amount increased with increase Mg loading. The medium basic sites were attributed to metal-oxygen pairs, namely Al-O, Mg-O [31]. XPS analysis To further explore the mechanism of interaction between Pd NPs and support, the XPS spectra was used to examine the electronic state of palladium species. The XPS results of Pd for Pd/Al2O3, Pd/MgO-Al2O3–2 and Pd/MgO-Al2O3–4 are shown in Fig. 3 . In case of Pd/Al2O3, the XPS spectrum of Pd 3d is well fitted to two pairs of peaks correspond to 3d5/2, 3d3/2 of Pd0 and 3d5/2, 3d3/2 of Pd2+, respectively. The one pair of less intense peaks can correspond to Pd 3d5/2 (at 334.9 eV) and Pd 3d3/2 photoelectron peaks of Pd0, and the other pair of more intense peaks can be assigned to Pd 3d5/2 (at 337.4 eV) and Pd 3d3/2 photoelectron peaks of Pd2+. For Pd/MgO-Al2O3–2 and Pd/MgO-Al2O3–4 samples, the binding energy of Pd 3d5/2 of Pd2+ decreased 0.2 eV to 337.2 eV and 0.5 eV to 336.9 eV, respectively (see Table 2 ), and there was some interference from Mg KL3 Auger peak with Pd 3d peaks [31]. This shift may indicate that Pd metal particles supported on MgO-Al2O3 are negatively charged according to the previous research [31], and the electrons are transferred from the support to Pd atoms, which leads to higher Pd NPs electron density. It is worth noting that the proportion of metallic state of the Pd element increases and reaches a maximum as the loading reaches 2 wt%. The results reveal that an interaction exists between Pd NPs and supports. Along with the NH3-TPD results, it can be deduced that acidic sites and basic sites interact with Pd NPs: the metallics are electron-deficient on acidic carriers and electron-rich on alkaline ones [31,41,42]. TEM analysis The structure and distribution of Pd NPs in the pure and alkaline, alkaline earth metals modified Pd/Al2O3 were investigated by TEM characterization (Fig. 4 ). The TEM images clearly illustrate that Pd NPs uniformly dispersed on the supports, Pd/Al2O3 and Pd/CsF-Al2O3 were the same size, and the size of Pd NPs decreased apparently to about 3.75 nm in the wake of increasing loading of Mg [30]. The interaction between the MgO layer or support and metal particles can inhibit the growth of Pd NPs and play a critical role. Catalytic performance of Pd catalysts The catalytic performance of the Pd supported on different Al2O3 was studied and depicted in Fig. 5 . The conversion and selectivity over commercial acidic, medium and basic γ-Al2O3 of Pd catalysts have no significant differences. After the modification with alkali metal and alkali earth metal, the Pd catalysts exhibit better catalytic activity except Pd/ZnO-Al2O3, and the conversion and selectivity show a volcanic-type variation trend with rising MgO coverage. According to the above analyses, the MgO coating can apparently decrease the surface strong acid sites of Pd/Al2O3, which contributed to the promotion of selectivity of C6F12H2 in the previous research [25–27]. In other words, the weak acidity of the support surface was beneficial to the selectivity. This is further confirmed by the relation of Mg addition and C6F12H2 selectivity (Table 3 ). With the increase of Mg addition, the C6F12H2 selectivity increase, the C6F11H-4 selectivity first decrease and then increase slightly, the hexafluoropropene trimer T3 selectivity first increase and then decrease. Since the C6F11H-4 derived from the dehydrofluorination process of C6F12H2, and the dehydrofluorination was linked directly to the interaction between the strong acid site and the F atom; the introduction of Mg effectively reduced the amounts of the strong acid sites, thus the C6F12H2 selectivity was improved; on the other hand, the hexafluoropropene trimer T3 selectivity increased slightly may due to the basic sites be served as an active site on the polymerization process; the alkali metal such as CsF usually be used as a catalyst in the dimerization of hexafluoropropylene. On the one hand, the C = C bond of C6F12 was electron-deficient state, the transfer of electrons from MgO-Al2O3 carriers Pd NPs and increased the electron density around Pd NPs and improved the activation ability for the C=C bond, thus promoting the activation of C = C. On the other hand, the reduction of reducibility of PdO supported on the MgO-Al2O3 carrier led to a more metallic state Pd [33]; In general hydrogenation, the active component is known as the metallic state. The increase of metallic state contributed to the improvement of conversion. In brief, the contribution of Mg to the selectivity can be attributed to inhibiting the dehydrofluorination of C6F12H2 via weakening the interaction between the strong acid sites and F atoms, while the contribution to the conversion can be ascribed to the improved activation ability, such as increasing the electron density and the amount of metallic state Pd. In the end, the effects of reductant on the catalytic properties were studied. The results indicate that the D1 conversion and C6F12H2 selectivity employed the catalysts reduced by hydrazine hydrate solution or sodium borohydride solution possess similar performance, and reduced by H2 exerts worst catalytic properties (Fig. S4a) with 4.60 nm of Pd NPs (Fig. S4b). However, the size of Pd NPs is the same as the Al2O3 sample modified by 2 wt% Mg, indicating that the Pd NPs size is not the only factor based on TEM data and aforementioned research. The stability of the Pd/MgO-Al2O3–2 catalyst was investigated on a fixed-bed microreactor (Fig. 6 ). The selectivity improved by ∼ 23% compared with the results of a batch reactor, which may be due to the shorter residence time of the fixed-bed microreactor than the batch reactor, the residence time were 20 s and 6 h, respectively. The short residence time avoids excessive hydrogenation and the subsequent formation of by-products. At the same time, the catalyst still maintained high catalytic performance after 48 h reaction. TEM was used to detect the Pd NPs size after 48 h, and the Pd NPs diameter was about 5.0 nm, as shown in Fig. 6b. Mechanism exploration of the Pd catalysts The role of MgO and the reaction mechanism were investigated by the DFT calculation. The catalyst model structures of the Pd13 cluster on γ-Al2O3 (100) and MgO/γ-Al2O3 (100) were also optimized and shown in Fig. 7 . In consideration of the dissociation for H2 can be modulated via pressure and then exert influence on the judgment of the rate-determining-step, the pressure correction term was introduced to calibrate the free energy of H*. Possible reaction pathways for D1 hydrogenation are listed in Scheme 1 . Generally, D1 adsorbed on the Pd catalyst surface (Scheme 1) reacts with H* from H2 dissociation, there are two paths for hydrogenation of C6F12* to obtain C6F12H*, in which the blue and black lines indicate target reaction and side reaction, respectively. The C6F12H* on the blue line continues to react with H* to form C6F12H2*. Furtherly, this is a complex process to generate the target product C6F12H2 from C6F12H2*, because there are five side reactions that the C6F12H2* intermediate is easier to generate the C6F11H* and then desorb from the catalyst surface to form the different configurations of the C6F11H outgrowth. In addition, hydrogenation, dehydrofluorination and addition of HF may occur via the key intermediates such as C6F12H2* and C6F12*, and generates a series of accessory substance (such as C6F11H3 and C6F13H). For Pd/MgO-Al2O3–2 catalyst, the reaction steps and intermediates were investigated based on the Gibbs free energy by DFT calculation, the corresponding adsorption configuration was presented in Scheme 1, Fig. 8 , and Fig. S5-S7. Firstly, the formation of C6F12H* can be from the hydrogenation on C2 or C3 of C6F12, and the rate-determining step was the addition of the first hydrogen on C6F12 molecules. The C6F12H*−1 exhibits a lower energy barrier (0.174 eV) than C6F12H*−2 (0.216 eV), which indicates the formation of C6F12H*−1 was the main pathway for the next step (Scheme 1). It was elucidated that the central carbon (C3) was more negative and the addition of hydrogen was more difficult [23,24]. Meanwhile, the other possible reason is that the steric hindrance on the C3 is bigger than C2 as the increasing substituent groups around C3, for instance -CF3, -CF- and -F. Secondly, the C6F12H*−1 promoted further hydrogenation of H* to C6F12H2*, which favored desorption from the surface to generate the final C6F12H2. The essential principle in heterogeneous catalysis, as Paul Sabatier and others pointed out, is that the strength of interaction between a catalyst and the reactants should be just enough, neither too strong nor too weak [59,60]. Thus, hydrogenation and dehydrofluorination may occur via the key intermediates such as C6F12H2*, and generate a series of accessory substances. As shown in Scheme 2 a, a comparison of four dehydrofluorination pathways for C6F12H2* (Side 3–6): The elimination reaction side 4 more easily forms C6F11H*−4 (0.224 eV) than the others, the high desorption energy barriers from the surface of different C6F11H* intermediates significantly hinder it from the further reacting. Subsequently, the intermediate C6F11H*−4 desorbed from the catalyst surface or reacted with H* to generate the side products C6F11H and C6F11H3. Meanwhile, dehydrofluorination of C6F12H2* further occurred on the catalyst surface to form the side product C6F11H (Scheme 2a). What is noteworthy is that the dehydrofluorination reaction follows E2 mechanism instead of E1 according to the DFT calculation results that side 4 of E2 (0.224 eV) possess lower free energy barrier than E1 (0.263 eV) (Scheme 2a and Scheme S1a). Finally, compared with the hydrogenation, the addition of HF is easier (Scheme 2b), which leads to a worse selectivity, the intermediate C6F12* tends to combine with HF from reaction process to form C6F13H*. As seen from the calculation results in Scheme 2b, the energy barrier C6F13H*−1 (Side 7, 0.294 eV) is lower than C6F13H*−2 (Side 8, 0.292eV). The stable intermediate C6F13H* could desorb from the catalyst surface directly to form the side product C6F13H. Therefore, competition between desorption and further reaction of these key intermediates made a considerable difference in the selectivity of the hydrogenation for C6F12. Considering that the MgO coating γ- Al2O3 can increase the conversion rate and selectivity of D1 hydrogenation, the optimal reaction steps (Target, Side 4, Side 7) and intermediates of Pd/Al2O3 catalyst were also investigated based on the Gibbs free energy by DFT calculation, the Gibbs free energy profiles, the corresponding adsorption configuration were shown in Fig. 9 and Fig. S5-S7. Based on the results of the Pd/MgO-Al2O3 catalyst, further calculation of hydrogenation on the C2 for Pd/Al2O3 catalyst was conducted to clarify the role of MgO. The hydrogenation on the C2 for the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst is more difficult, the Gibbs free energy barrier is 0.861 eV (Scheme S1c), almost five times as much as the Pd/MgO-Al2O3–2 catalyst. The above results indicate that the introduction of MgO efficiently promotes the activation of C6F12, which decreases the Gibbs free energy barriers of activation for C6F12 on Pd/MgO-Al2O3–2 catalyst. Previous studies indicated that the metallics were electron-deficient on acidic carriers and electron-rich on alkaline ones [31,41,42]. XPS analysis suggested that the electrons were transferred from the carrier to the Pd, increasing the electron density around Pd NPs, and increasing the content of metallic state Pd. The synergistic effect of the increase of electron density around Pd NPs and the content of metallic state Pd contribute to the improvement of the activation ability and C6F12 conversion. From the energy barriers of optimal pathways comparison for dehydrofluorination (Scheme 2a, Scheme S1d, Scheme 2b, Scheme S1e), addition of HF on Pd/MgO-Al2O3–2 and Pd/Al2O3 catalysts, it seems that the former possesses the worse selectivity, this result is somewhat different with the experimental data. Therefore, the selectivity of the main products is further analyzed and depicted in Table 2. With the addition of 2 wt% Mg, the selectivity of C6F12H2 improves by 19.27%, in which C6F11H accounted for 2.89% and hexafluoropropene Trimer T3 accounted without obvious changes. The contribution of the promotion of the decrease for C6F11H-4 is about 2.65% while the hexafluoropropene Trimer T3 is 0.13% as the content of Mg is increased to 8 wt%. And the contribution of the former increases slightly and the latter stays the same. The above results reveal that the introduction of MgO inhibits the formation of HF and the polymerization of C6F12 to some extent. The improvement of C6F12H2 selectivity may be ascribed to the Mg inhibited the dehydrofluorination of C6F12H2. Since the C6F11H-4 derived from the dehydrofluorination process of C6F12H2, and the dehydrofluorination was linked directly to the interaction between the strong acid site and the F atom; the introduction of Mg effectively reduced the amounts of the strong acid sites according to the NH3-TPD analysis, thus the C6F12H2 selectivity was improved. Eventually, the further hydrogenation of C6F11H*−4 on Pd/MgO-Al2O3–2 catalyst is studied assuming that the formation of C6F11H2* can be from the hydrogenation on C2 of C6F11H*−4, and the adsorption configuration are shown in Fig. S6c and S6g, Fig. S6d and Fig. S6h. The energy barrier (- 0.654 eV) of the addition for the first hydrogen is lower than this in C6F12*(0.174 eV), and the rate-determining-step is the desorption of C6F11H3* from the catalyst surface (Scheme S1b), which is a significant difference from the latter. Conclusion In summary, Pd catalysts supported by Al2O3 and modified Al2O3 were successfully prepared for the hydrogenation of D1. In comparison to Pd/Al2O3 catalysts, the Pd/MgO-Al2O3–2 catalyst exhibited the improved conversion, selectivity, and good stability. It was attributed to the introduction of MgO, which increased the electron density around Pd NPs, reduced the reduction capacity of palladium and numbers of strong acid sites and, thus resulted in more metallic state palladium and weaker acid sites and then improved the conversion and selectivity. Furthermore, we reported a detailed DFT study exploring the hydrogenation process over Pd/MgO-Al2O3 and Pd/Al2O3 catalysts. The calculated results revealed the probable mechanism of C6F12H2 formation with different side products, and the rate-determining step of the first hydrogen on the C6F12 molecule. A comparison of the experimental findings with the DFT study indicated good overall agreement. These findings provide an effective strategy for regulating noble metal catalysts in the synthesis of fluorine chemical products. coredata.dc:description: Gamma alumina is widely utilized for preparing the supported noble metal catalysts for the hydrogenation reaction. It is an effective strategy to improve the catalytic performance of catalysts via modifying gamma alumina with alkaline earth metal to regulate its surface acidity and electronic properties. Herein, Pd catalysts supported by Al2O3 and Mg-modified Al2O3 are synthesized via the wet impregnation method, and the effects of MgO doping on the structure, composition, and surface acidity of Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts are investigated via X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD), Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Temperature programmed desorption (TPD). The results show that Pd/MgO-Al2O3–2 (γ-Al2O3 modified with 2 wt% Mg) has more metallic state palladium and weak acid sites and exhibits the best catalytic performance for the hydrogenation of perfluoro-4-methyl-2-pentene (D1). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations on Pd/Al2O3 and Pd/MgO-Al2O3–2 catalysts are also performed to further explore the mechanism of D1 hydrogenation. The studies for Gibbs free energy of the potential reaction steps and intermediates reveal a complex process to generate the target product C6F12H2, and the rate-determining-step is the addition of the first hydrogen on the second carbon of perfluoro-4-methyl-2-pentene molecule.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of MgO doping in Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts forthe hydrogenation of perfluoro olefin
